bibl.title: Euripides' Ur-Medea between Hypotheseis and Declamation.
bibl.note: Response to: Wolfgang LUPPE, Ein weiteres Zeugnis für zwei Μήδεια-Dramen des Euripides, ZPE 173 (2010) pp. 15-16. Discussion on P. I.F.A.O. Inv. P.S.P. 248 (= M.-P.3 454.3; LDAB 917) and P. Oxy. ined. [descr.: Peter PARSONS, New Greek Texts from Oxyrhynchus, British Academy Review 14 (2009) p. 30]. "As the forthcoming editio princeps will illustrate in detail, the Oxyrhynchus papyrus does not provide sound evidence for a Ur-Medea by Euripides; rather it must be taken for what it actually is: an interesting text documenting the reception and exploitation of the classical heritage in later times within the rhetorical practice of the Second Sophistic."
bibl.seg: COLOMO Daniela, Euripides' Ur-Medea between Hypotheseis and Declamation.

Response to: Wolfgang LUPPE, Ein weiteres Zeugnis für zwei Μήδεια-Dramen des Euripides, ZPE 173 (2010) pp. 15-16. Discussion on P. I.F.A.O. Inv. P.S.P. 248 (= M.-P.3 454.3; LDAB 917) and P. Oxy. ined. [descr.: Peter PARSONS, New Greek Texts from Oxyrhynchus, British Academy Review 14 (2009) p. 30]. "As the forthcoming editio princeps will illustrate in detail, the Oxyrhynchus papyrus does not provide sound evidence for a Ur-Medea by Euripides; rather it must be taken for what it actually is: an interesting text documenting the reception and exploitation of the classical heritage in later times within the rhetorical practice of the Second Sophistic."
